member.summary: Determine whether the specified grid is an ittoryu puzzle, meaning the puzzle can be finished via digits one by one.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Algorithm.Ittoryu.IttoryuExtensions.IsIttoryu(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.Categorization.TechniqueSet,System.Nullable{Sudoku.Algorithm.Ittoryu.DigitPath}@)
member.summary: Determine whether the specified grid is an ittoryu puzzle, meaning the puzzle can be finished via digits one by one, with checking using the specified techniques.

param.name: techniques
param.para: The techniques supported.

The value is a instance. You can only chose one or more fields in the following list:
(Full House)
(Hidden Single in Block)
(Hidden Single in Row)
(Hidden Single in Column)
(Naked Single)
For example, [Technique.FullHouse, Technique.NakedSingle] is valid argument, but [Technique.NakedPair] is not.

target.name: method
target.summary: Deconstruct the current instance into multiple values, which means you can use the value-tuple syntax to define your own deconstruction logic.

remarks.para:
For example, if you have defined a deconstruction method Deconstruct in a , without any return value:
public static void Deconstruct(out string name, out int age) => (name, age) = (Name, Age);
The following code will be legal.
(string name, int age) = student; // Explicitly-typed variables var (name, age) = student; // Implicitly-typed variables

member.summary: Defines a context that is used by step searchers to check the details of the solving and analysis information.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.IsPearl
member.summary: Indicates whether the puzzle is a pearl puzzle, which means the first step must be an indirect technique usage.
member.returns:
Returns a ? value indicating the result. The values are:
Value Meaning
The puzzle has a unique solution, and the first set step has same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has a unique solution, but the first set step does not have same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has multiple solutions, or the puzzle has no valid solution.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.IsDiamond
member.summary: Indicates whether the puzzle is a diamond puzzle, which means the first deletion has the same difficulty with the maximum difficulty of the whole steps.
member.returns:
Returns a ? value indicating the result. The values are:
Value Meaning
The puzzle has a unique solution, and the first deletion step has same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has a unique solution, but the first deletion step does not have same difficulty with the whole steps.
The puzzle has multiple solutions, or the puzzle has no valid solution.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.MaxDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the maximum difficulty of the puzzle.
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the maximum value among all difficulty ratings in solving steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, or else the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be always 20.0M.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.TotalDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the total difficulty rating of the puzzle.
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved by , the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps. If the puzzle has not been solved, the value will be the sum of all difficulty ratings of steps recorded in . However, if the puzzle is solved by other solvers, this value will be 0.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.PearlDifficulty
member.summary: Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
member.remarks: When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first delete step that cause a set.
member.seealso: Concept for EP, ER and ED

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.DiamondDifficulty

summary.para: Indicates the pearl difficulty rating of the puzzle, calculated during only by .
When the puzzle is solved, the value will be the difficulty rating of the first delete step.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.AnalyzerResult.SteppingGrids
member.summary: Indicates a list, whose element is the intermediate grid for each step.

summary.para: Indicates a list of pairs of information about each step.
If the puzzle cannot be solved due to some reason (invalid puzzle, unhandled exception, etc.), the return value of the property will be always .

Indicates the wrong step found. In general cases, if the property keeps value, it'll mean the puzzle is invalid to solve, or the solver has found one error step to apply, that causes the original puzzle become invalid. In this case we can check this property to get the wrong information to debug the error, or tell the author himself directly, with the inner value of this property held.
However, if the puzzle is successful to be solved, the property won't contain any value, so it'll keep the reference. Therefore, please check the nullability of this property before using.

In general, this table will tell us the nullability of this property:
Nullability Description
Not The puzzle is failed to solve, and the solver has found an invalid step to apply.
Other cases.

summary.para: Represents cached fields used by solving and analyzing for a sudoku puzzle, reducing repeated and redundant calculations.

All names of fields given in this type can also be found in type , but those values are defined as instant properties, which means the value will be calculated after you invoke them. For example, if we use a property of them for 5 times, the result value will be calculated for 5 times.

Sometimes, such values may only be calculated only once, and we just use those return values after the value had been calculated. For the consideration of the calculation result caching, those results will be stored here as fields, we can use them if we can ensure that such fields have already been initialized. For calling the method , we can ensure those fields are initialized, in order to be used later. In other words, you must ensure the method having been called before using such fields if you want to use them; otherwise, will be thrown for cached fields whose types are reference ones.
The reason why I defined them as fields is that they are cached values. "" means caching, and "field" means the value to be fetched without encapsulation, for a better performance.
Some s may rely on this type.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Categorization.TechniqueExtensions.GetAbbreviation(Sudoku.Analytics.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Try to get the abbreviation of the current .
member.returns: The abbreviation of the current technique.
member.remarks:
The routing rule can be described as below:
Check whether the field is marked attribute , and return property value if marked.
If 1) returns , then search for resource dictionary, and return the target value if found.
If 2) returns , then check its , then return its abbreviation if worth.
If 3) returns , this method will return ; otherwise, a valid value.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason
member.summary: Defines a reason why the puzzle is failed to be analyzed.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.Nothing
member.summary: Indicates nothing goes wrong.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.PuzzleIsInvalid

summary.para: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid unique solution.
Different with and , this field will include more generic cases. If the puzzle doesn't pass the pre-process operation before solving, we should use this field.

member.remarks: This field can also be used for false-positive on analyzing a puzzle, raising .

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.PuzzleHasNoSolution
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle doesn't contain a valid solution.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.PuzzleHasMultipleSolutions
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle contains multiple valid solutions.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.UserCancelled
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the user has canceled the task.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.NotImplemented
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver or some searching module isn't implemented.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.ExceptionThrown
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has encountered an error and couldn't solve that will cause an exception thrown.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.WrongStep
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the solver has found a wrong step that cause the grid become invalid.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Metadata.FailedReason.PuzzleIsTooHard
member.summary: Indicates the failed reason is that the puzzle is too hard to solve. The solver gave up.

remarks.i: This option becomes deprecated at present because we has already implemented a step searcher that always produces a valid step, guaranteeing that the solver will never give up at all time.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Step.Format
member.summary: Gets the format of the current instance.
member.returns: Returns a result. If the resource dictionary doesn't contain any valid formats here, the result value will be .

remarks.para: A format is a way to describe the details to a technique usage (i.e. ). A format text will be combined with two parts: literals and placeholders. Here is an example: "Cells {0}, with digits {1}"

The placeholders {0} and {1} will use normal characters '{', digit characters '0' or '1' and '}'. The internal values will be offered by another property called . In that property, the value (an array) will contain 2 elements that can fill with the placeholders {0} and {1} respectively.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.Step.FormatInterpolationParts

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.DeathBlossomStepSearcher.SearchExtendedTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the step searcher searches for extended types.

remarks.para: This searcher uses a trick that starts with eliminations. From the solution, we can learn which candidates can be removed from the grid in fact.

Just suppose one of them is correct, and this case will lead to a confliction if some ALSes related to that supposed digit can lead to a same cell to be null (i.e. no digits can be filled). Therefore, we can remove the supposed digit from the containing cell.
This algorithm just makes the calculation simplified, in order to avoid complex searching on ALSes and a same-deletion leading.

member.summary: Create a instance and add it into the accumulator.

member.summary: Indicates the level of dynamic recursion. The value can be 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.
member.remarks:
All possible values corresponds to their own cases respectively:
Value Supported nesting rule
0 Non-dynamic forcing chains
1 Dynamic forcing chains (+ Structural techniques, e.g. )
2 Dynamic forcing chains (+ AIC)
3 Dynamic forcing chains (+ Multiple forcing chains)
4 Dynamic forcing chains (+ Dynamic forcing chains)
5 Dynamic forcing chains (+ Dynamic forcing chains (+))

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.MultipleChainingStepSearcher.Collect(Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisContext@)
member.summary: Search for hints on the given grid.
member.param: The grid on which to search for hints.

summary.para: From the potential p, compute the consequences from both states.

More precisely, p is first assumed to be correct ("on"), and then to be incorrect ("off"); and the following sets are created:
the set of potentials that must be "on" when p is "on".
the set of potentials that must be "off" when p is "on".
offToOn the set of potentials that must be "on" when p is "off".
offToOff the set of potentials that must be "off" when p is "off".
Then the following rules are applied:
If a potential belongs to both and , the potential p cannot be "on" because it would imply a potential to be both "on" and "off", which is an absurd.
If a potential belongs to both offToOn and offToOff, the potential p cannot be "off" because it would imply a potential to be both "on" and "off", which is an absurd.
If a potential belongs to both and offToOn, this potential must be "on", because it is implied to be "on" by the two possible states of p.
If a potential belongs to both and offToOff, this potential must be "off", because it is implied to be "off" by the two possible states of p.
Note that if a potential belongs to all the four sets, the sudoku has no solution. This is not checked.

member.param: An empty set, filled with potentials that get on if the given potential is on.
An empty set, filled with potentials that get off if the given potential is on.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.BorescoperDeadlyPatternStepSearcher.Pattern
member.summary:
Defines a pattern that is a Borescoper's Deadly Pattern technique pattern in theory. The sketch is like:
.-------.-------.-------. | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | . . . | | . . . | . . . | P P . | :-------+-------+-------: | . . . | . . Q | S S . | | . . . | . . Q | S(S). | | . . . | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
Where:
PThe first group of cells.
QThe second group of cells.
S
The square cells of size 3 or 4. The cell with the bracket (r8c8 in the picture) is optional.

param.name: mask
param.para: Indicates the internal mask.

This mask is of type , where the distribution of each bit is as follows:
0 7 14 21 28 35 42 49 56
|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|-------|
0 8 16 24 32 40 48 56 64
where the bit [0..56] is for 8 cells, the last 7 bits determine the pattern is a heptagon or a octagon. If the value is 127 (not available), the pattern will be a heptagon.
Due to the rendering engine, you have to check this file rather than the tip window.

target.name: method

remarks.para:
For example, if you have defined a deconstruction method Deconstruct in a , without any return value:
public static void Deconstruct(out string name, out int age) => (name, age) = (Name, Age);
The following code will be legal.
(string name, int age) = student; // Explicitly-typed variables var (name, age) = student; // Implicitly-typed variables

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueLoopStepSearcher.IsValidLoop(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Int32})
member.summary: Determine whether the specified loop is a valid unique loop or unique rectangle pattern.

remarks.para: This method uses a trick way (node-coloring) to check whether a loop is a unique loop. The parameter holds a list of cells, which are nodes of the loop. Then we begin to colorize each node with 2 different colors A and B. The only point we should notice is that the color between 2 adjacent nodes should be different (i.e. one is colored with A and the other should be colored with B). If at least one pair of cells in a same house are colored with a same color, it won't be a valid unique loop. Those colors stands for the final filling digits. Therefore, "Two cells in a same house are colored same" means "Two cells in a same house are filled with a same digit", which disobeys the basic sudoku rule.
This method won't check for whether the loop is a unique rectangle (of length 4). It means, a valid unique rectangle can also make this method return .

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Unique Rectangle step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Unique Rectangle Type 1-6
Avoidable Rectangle Type 1-3, 5
Hidden Unique Rectangle
Hidden Avoidable Rectangle
Constructed types:
Unique Rectangle + Conjugate Pair (also called "Unique Rectangle + Strong Link")
Avoidable Rectangle + Hidden Single
Unique Rectangle + Baba Grouping
Unique Rectangle + Sue de Coq
Unique Rectangle + XY-Wing, XYZ-Wing and WXYZ-Wing
Unique Rectangle + W-Wing
Unique/Avoidable Rectangle + Guardian (This program call it "External Types"):
Unique Rectangle External Type 1-4
Unique Rectangle External XY-Wing
Unique Rectangle External W-Wing
Unique Rectangle External ALS-XZ
Unique Rectangle External Turbot Fish
Miscellaneous types:
Unique Rectangle 2D, 3X

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.AllowIncompleteUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the UR can be incomplete. In other words, some of UR candidates can be removed before the pattern forms.
member.remarks:
For example, the complete pattern is:
ab | ab ab | ab
This is a complete pattern, and we may remove an ab in a certain corner. The incomplete pattern may not contain all four abs in the pattern.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.SearchForExtendedUniqueRectangles
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher can search for extended URs.
member.remarks: The basic types are type 1 to type 6, all other types are extended ones.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.Collect(System.Collections.Generic.List{Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep},Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisContext@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get all possible hints from the grid.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is searching for ARs.

member.summary: Check type 1.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (abc) ab ab ab

member.summary: Check type 2.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1, corner2 (abc) (abc) ab ab

member.summary: Check type 3.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) abx aby

member.summary: Check type 4.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1, corner2 (ab ) ab abx aby

member.summary: Check type 5.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab ) abc abc abc

member.summary: Check type 6.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1 (ab ) aby abx (ab) corner2

member.summary: Check hidden UR.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 2D.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1 (ab ) abx aby (ab ) xy * corner2

member.summary: Check UR + 2B/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1, corner2 (ab ) (ab ) | | a | abx aby

member.summary: Check UR + 2D/1SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1 (ab ) aby | | a | abx (ab ) corner2

member.summary: Check UR + 3X.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab ) abx aby abz xy *
Note: z is x or y.

member.summary: Check UR + 3X/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab ) abx | | b a | aby-----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3N/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a | | b | aby abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3U/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
b aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 3E/2SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
cornerCell (ab )-----abx a
a aby -----abz

member.summary: Check UR + 4X/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | b a | abz ----- abw

member.summary: Check UR + 4C/3SL.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) a | | a b | abz ----- abw

Subtype 2:
corner1, corner2 (abx)-----(aby) | a | | b | a | | abz abw

member.summary: Check UR-XY-Wing, UR-XYZ-Wing, UR-WXYZ-Wing and AR-XY-Wing, AR-XYZ-Wing and AR-WXYZ-Wing.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
Indicates whether the corner cells cannot see each other.

remarks.para: The structures:

Subtype 1:
corner1 (ab ) abxy yz xz (ab ) abxy * corner2
Note that the pair of cells abxy should be in the same house.

Subtype 2:
corner1 (ab ) abx xz aby (ab ) * yz corner2

member.summary: Check UR + SdC.
member.param: Indicates whether the current mode is AR mode.
The map of other cells during the current UR searching.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
| xyz ab+ ab+ | abxyz abxyz | xyz ----------+------------ (ab)(ab) | corner1, corner2

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.UniqueRectangleStepSearcher.CheckBabaGroupingUnique(System.Collections.Generic.List{Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep},Sudoku.Concepts.Grid@,Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisContext@,System.Int32[],System.Int16,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Check UR + baba grouping.
member.remarks:
The pattern:
urCellInSameBlock ab abc abc anotherCell
abcx-----abcy resultCell c targetCell
Where the digit a and b in the bottom-left cell abcx can be removed.

summary.para: Check UR/AR + Guardian (i.e. UR External Type 2) and UR External Type 1.
A UR external type 1 is a special case for type 2, which means only one guardian cell will be used.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.ExocetStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an Exocet step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Junior Exocet
Weak Exocet
Double Exocet
Senior Exocet
Complex Senior Exocet
Advanced Complex Senior Exocet
The core method to check for Junior Exocet sub-types.
member.param: The analysis context to be used for accumulate steps.
The grid as the candidate referencing object.
The cells of the target. The target cell only contains empty cells; non-empty ones will be ignored.
The grouped cells for the argument , by is containing crossline house.
The cells of cross-line. The cross-line cells contain 18 cells regardless of its state: empty or non-empty.
The mask that holds a list of digits that are appeared in base cells.
The mask that holds a list of houses being iterated.
Indicates whether the exocet pattern is row-ish. The direction is same as cross-line cells.
The size of houses used in the cross-line cells. The value can be 3 or 4; higher-sized cases cannot be determined because I don't know. :(
The chute index to be used. Valid values are between 0 and 6.
member.returns: A valid instance calculated and found.

Normal fishes:

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.NormalFishStepSearcher.DisableFinnedOrSashimiXWing

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an Almost Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Basic types:
Almost Locked Pair
Almost Locked Triple
Extended types (contains value cells):
Extended Almost Locked Triple
Extended Almost Locked Quadruple

member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher checks the almost locked quadruple.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.CheckValueTypes
member.summary: Indicates whether the searcher checks for value types.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.AlmostLockedCandidatesStepSearcher.Collect(Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisContext@,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,System.Boolean)
member.param: Indicates whether the method checks for value cells.

remarks.para:
The diagrams:
ALP: abx aby | ab abz |
ALT: abcw abcx | abc abc abcy abcz |
Algorithm:

If the cell ab (in ALP) or abc (in ALT) is filled with the digit p, then the cells abx and aby (in ALP) and abcw and abcx (in ALT) can't fill the digit p. Therefore the digit p can only be filled into the left-side block.
If the block only contains those cells that can contain the digit p, the ALP or ALT will be formed, and the elimination is z (in ALP) and y and z (in ALT).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.LockedCandidatesStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Locked Candidates step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Pointing
Claiming

remarks.para: The main idea of this searching operation:

.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
For example, if the cells C form a locked candidates, there'll be two cases:
Pointing (Type 1): Cells A contains the digit, but cells B doesn't.
Claiming (Type 2): Cells B contains the digit, but cells A doesn't.

Therefore, the algorithm is: Use bitwise-or operator | to gather all candidate masks from cells A, cells B and cells C, and suppose the notation a is the mask result for cells A, b is the mask result for cells B, and c is the mask result for cells C. If the equation (c & (a ^ b)) != 0 is correct, the locked candidates exists, and the result of the expression c & (a ^ b) is a mask that holds the digits of the locked candidates.

Why this expression? a ^ b means the digit can only appear in either cells A or cells B. If both or neither, the digit won't contain the locked candidates pattern. Because of the optimization of the performance, we use the predefined table to iterate on all possible location where may form a locked candidates.

Multiple-Branch W-Wing (Multiple-Branch George Woods' Wing)

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.WWingStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a W-Wing (George Woods' Wing) step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
W-Wing
Grouped W-Wing

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.RegularWingStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with a Regular Wing step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
XY-Wing
XYZ-Wing
WXYZ-Wing
VWXYZ-Wing
UVWXYZ-Wing
TUVWXYZ-Wing
STUVWXYZ-Wing
RSTUVWXYZ-Wing

member.name: P:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.RegularWingStepSearcher.MaxSearchingPivotsCount
member.summary: Indicates the maximum number of pivots to be searched for. The default value is 3.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.XyzRingStepSearcher
member.summary:
Provides with an XYZ-Ring step searcher. The step searcher will include the following techniques:
Non-Nice XYZ-Ring
Nice XYZ-Ring
Grouped Non-Nice XYZ-Ring
Grouped Nice XYZ-Ring

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.StepSearchers.XyzRingStepSearcher.Collect(Sudoku.Analytics.AnalysisContext@)
member.remarks:
Developer Notes
The pattern is nearly equals an XYZ-Wing + a conjugate pair.
abc. . | ab . . . . . | . . . . . . | . . . ---------+-------- ac . . | . . . . . . | . . . . . a | a . . conjugate pair of 'a'
Or
abc. . | ab . . . . . | . . . . . . | . . . ---------+-------- ac . . | . . . . . . | . . . a . . | a . . conjugate pair of 'a'

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.UniqueRectangleStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Unique Rectangle technique.
member.param: Indicates the second digit used. This value is always greater than .
Indicates the cells used in this pattern.
Indicates whether the current rectangle is an avoidable rectangle. If , an avoidable rectangle; otherwise, a unique rectangle.

param.name: absoluteOffset
param.para: Indicates the absolute offset.

The value is an value, as an index, in order to distinct with all unique rectangle patterns. The greater the value is, the later the corresponding pattern will be processed. The value must be between 0 and 485, because the total number of possible patterns is 486.

member.summary: Provides with a step that is an Exocet technique.
member.param: Indicates the mask that holds a list of digits used in the pattern.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.ExocetStep.#ctor(Sudoku.Analytics.Conclusion[],Sudoku.Rendering.View[],Sudoku.Analytics.Configuration.StepSearcherOptions,System.Int16,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@)
member.summary: Provides with a step that is an Exocet technique.
member.param: Indicates the mask that holds a list of digits used in the pattern.

summary.para: Indicates the delta value of the pattern.

The values can be -2, -1, 0, 1 and 2, separated with 3 groups:
Value Description
-2 or -1 (< 0) The base contain more cells than the target, meaning the pattern will be a "Senior Exocet"
1 or 2 (> 0)
The target contain more cells than the base, meaning the pattern will contain extra items like conjugate pairs of other digits
0 The base has same number of cells with the target, a standard "Junior Exocet" will be formed

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.ComplexFishStep
member.summary: Provides with a step that is a Complex Fish technique.
member.param: Indicates the fins, positioned outside the fish. They will be defined if cover sets cannot be fully covered, with the number of cover sets being equal to the number of base sets.
Indicates the fins, positioned inside the fish. Generally speaking, they will be defined if they are in multiple base sets.
Indicates whether the fish is a Franken fish. If , a Franken fish; otherwise, a Mutant fish.

param.name: isSashimi
param.para: Indicates whether the fish is a Sashimi fish.

All cases are as below:
The fish is a sashimi finned fish.
The fish is a normal finned fish.
The fish doesn't contain any fin.

member.param: Indicates whether the fish contains any cannibalism.

The name of the corresponding names are:
2X-Wing
3Swordfish
4Jellyfish
5Squirmbag (or Starfish)
6Whale
7Leviathan
Other fishes of sizes not appearing in above don't have well-known names.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishFinKind.Finned
member.summary: Indicates the finned fish (i.e. contains fins, but the fish may be regular when the fins are removed).

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishFinKind.Sashimi
member.summary: Indicates the sashimi fish (i.e. contains fins, and the fish may be degenerated to hidden singles when the fins are removed).

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishFinKind.Siamese
member.summary: Indicates the Siamese fish (i.e. two fish share same base sets, with different cover sets).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishShapeKind
member.summary: Indicates a shape modifier that is used for a complex fish pattern.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishShapeKind.Basic
member.summary: Indicates the basic fish.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishShapeKind.Franken
member.summary: Indicates the franken fish.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Analytics.Steps.FishShapeKind.Mutant
member.summary: Indicates the mutant fish.

member.summary: Gets all possible aliased names that are defined by Hodoku.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Compatibility.Hodoku.HodokuCompatibility.GetHodokuPrefix(Sudoku.Analytics.Categorization.Technique)
member.summary: Try to get the prefix of the specified technique. The return value will be a four-digit value represented as a value. For more information please visit this link.

returns.para: A value using a four-digit value to describe a technique used in a sudoku grid, which is defined by the project Hodoku.
If this technique is not supported by Hodoku, will be returned.

remarks.para: Please note that some technique fields are separated into multiple sub-types, but they all belong to a same type of a technique supported by Hodoku. For example, and are supported by Hodoku as one technique "Sue de Coq", so if you get the prefix from the two fields, the return value are same (i.e. the value "1101").

member.exception: Throws when the specified value is not defined by the type , or the value is .

member.name: M:Sudoku.Compatibility.Hodoku.HodokuCompatibility.GetDifficultyRating(Sudoku.Analytics.Categorization.Technique,System.Nullable{Sudoku.Compatibility.Hodoku.HodokuDifficultyLevel}@)
member.summary: Try to get difficulty rating of the specified technique.
member.param: The difficulty level that is defined by Hodoku.

returns.para: An value defined by the project Hodoku.
If this technique is not supported by Hodoku, will be returned.

member.exception: Throws when the specified value is not defined by the type , or the value is .

(string name, int age) = student; // Explicitly-typed variables var (name, age) = student; // Implicitly-typed variables

member.name: T:Sudoku.Concepts.AlmostLockedSet
member.summary: Defines a data pattern that describes an ALS.
member.param: Indicates the mask of digits used.
Gets the possible cells that can store eliminations for the ALS.
The cells that can be eliminated, grouped by digit. The former 9 elements of the array is the cells that can be eliminated for the corresponding digit, and the last element is the merged cells.
member.remarks: An Almost Locked Set is a sudoku concept, which describes a case that n cells contains (n + 1) kinds of different digits. The special case is a bi-value cell.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Concepts.AlmostLockedSet.#ctor(System.Int16,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap@,Sudoku.Concepts.CellMap[])
member.summary: Defines a data pattern that describes an ALS.
member.param: Indicates the mask of digits used.
Gets the possible cells that can store eliminations for the ALS.
The cells that can be eliminated, grouped by digit. The former 9 elements of the array is the cells that can be eliminated for the corresponding digit, and the last element is the merged cells.
member.remarks: An Almost Locked Set is a sudoku concept, which describes a case that n cells contains (n + 1) kinds of different digits. The special case is a bi-value cell.

member.summary: Indicates all strong links in this ALS. The result will be represented as a mask of 9 bits indicating which bits used.

summary.para: Indicates the parents of the current instance.
The result always returns a list of length 1 if the chain is not dynamic. In addition, if a instance has no available parent (i.e. the return collection is empty), it must the head of a chain.

b.i: If you want to append more parent nodes into the current instance, just call to add it using this property: p.Parents.Add(parent);. However, please don't call other methods like because it can be only used by creating a dynamic chains.

member.remarks:
Pattern:
(rating|name|conclusion)
Options:
RegexOptions.IgnoreCase | RegexOptions.Compiled
Explanation:
1st capture group.
Match with 3 alternative expressions, atomically.
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [Rr].
Match a character in the set [Aa].
Match a character in the set [Tt].
Match a character in the set [Ii].
Match a character in the set [Nn].
Match a character in the set [Gg].
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [Nn].
Match a character in the set [Aa].
Match a character in the set [Mm].
Match a character in the set [Ee].
Match a sequence of expressions.
Match a character in the set [Cc].
Match a character in the set [Oo].
Match a character in the set [Nn].
Match a character in the set [Cc].
Match a character in the set [Ll].
Match a character in the set [Uu].
